thread.title: Football: Hannon powers Har-Ber past No. 1 Fayetteville
thread.title_full: Football: Hannon powers Har-Ber past No. 1 Fayetteville

title: Football: Hannon powers Har-Ber past No. 1 Fayetteville
text:
Enlarge NWA Democrat-Gazette/ANDY SHUPE Luke Hannon (34) of Springdale Har-Ber rumbles past Joey Savin (12) and Colby Sigears (6) of ... 
Both numbers were worn by senior Luke Hannon, who had to change at halftime because of a torn jersey. 
Springdale Har-Ber 47, Fayetteville 43 
Fayetteville^8^14^7^14— ^43 
Har-Ber^14^6^13^14—^47 
First Quarter 
Harb — Blackston 17 pass from Chandler (Zizumbo kick), 9:38 
Fay — Morris 21 pass from Powell (pass good), 7:59 
Harb — Hannon 7 run (Zizumbo kick), 4:18 
Second Quarter 
Fay — Morris 19 pass from Powell (Fagg kick), 10:56 
Fay — Rapert 18 run (Fagg kick), 5:04 
Harb — Hannon 28 pass from Chandler (kick failed), 0:00 
Third Quarter 
Harb — Hannon 1 run (pass failed), 7:40 
Fay — Wymer 18 pass from Powell (Fagg kick), 4:46 
Harb — Hannon 19 run (Zizumbo kick), 1:55 
Fourth Quarter 
Harb — Hannon 3 run (Zizumbo kick), 9:46 
Fay — Smith 54 run (pass failed), 9:17 
Fay — Smith 7 run (run good), 5:48 
Harb — Smith 5 pass from Chandler (Zizumbo kick), 0:06 
Hannon rushed for four touchdowns and caught a touchdown pass to lead No. 2 Har-Ber to a 47-43 victory over No. 1 Fayetteville on Friday in a 7A-West Conference showdown at Wildcat Stadium. 
Fayetteville took the lead in the fourth quarter before Trey Smith won it for Har-Ber on a 6-yard touchdown catch from Fuller Chandler with six seconds remaining. 
Har-Ber (6-1, 4-0) takes over the lead in the 7A-West Conference after posting consecutive victories over Fayetteville (6-1, 3-1) and defending 7A state champion Bentonville. 
"It's always great to win games in the 7A-West. They're a cherished prize," Har-Ber coach Chris Wood said following his team's sixth consecutive victory. "We'll take it but no one remembers what happens in October. You've got to win games in November and December." 
Hannon had the best game of his career with 318 yards rushing on 45 carries. He also scored on a 28-yard touchdown pass from Fuller Chandler to end the first half. Chandler lofted the ball high and it appeared a Fayetteville defender was going to come down with the Bulldogs' third interception of the half. But Hannon took the ball away from a Fayetteville defender who tried for the interception instead of knocking the ball down. 
"Luke Hannon is a special talent," Har-Ber coach Chris Wood said. "He's a game-changer and we want the ball in his hands." 
Hannon scored twice in the third quarter on touchdowns of 1 and 18 yards to put Har-Ber ahead 33-29. But Fayetteville took a 43-40 lead with 5 minutes, 48 seconds left in the fourth quarter after two touchdown runs by Javontae Smith. 
Har-Ber then marched steadily downfield behind the running of Hannon, who added a 17-yard catch on the drive. Hannon ran for 15 yards before Chandler found Smith alone in the middle of the end zone for the winning touchdown. 
"That was a great drive," Fayetteville coach Daryl Patton said. "You have to tip your hat to them. They're a great football team. That was a hell of a game." 
Fayetteville's potent offense began to kick in after the Bulldogs trailed 14-8 after one quarter. Taylor Powell completed his second touchdown pass to Tyson Morris before Luke Rapert scored on an 18-yard run to give Fayetteville a 22-14 lead. That scored looked like it was going to stand until Hannon came down with the 28-yard heave from Chandler to pull the Wildcats to within 22-20 at halftime. 
Har-Ber led 14-8 after one quarter on a 17-yard touchdown pass to Tyler Blackston and a 7-yard touchdown run from Hannon, who had 132 yards rushing in the first half despite a slow start. Jesus Zizumbo missed a 29-yard field goal after Blackston had a touchdown catch called back because of a penalty on an ineligible player down field. 
Tyson Morris scored Fayetteville's first touchdown on a 21-yard catch and the Bulldogs went ahead 8-7 on a 2-point conversion pass by Powell. Har-Ber regained the lead after a juggling 57-yard reception by Dalton Douangdara gave the Wildcats a first down at the Fayetteville 5-yard line.
